vulnerability.size: The more population, the larger the dot.

content.title: Objective of the tool:
content.description: The ARTUR Tool has been designed as an interactive platform that serves as a resilience checker for Ukrainian cities. The specific tasks within this tool include:
content.step1: 1. Dissect the challenges of a city.
content.step2: 2. Diagnose the causes and effects of its challenges.

step2.title: Step 2
step2.content: From the identified types of challenges in this city, please select the one you would like to consult. Afterwards, click

step3.title: Step 3
step3.content: Please open the dashboard and then select one type of disruption in the top diagram to evaluate in the map. Afterwards, click

summary.water: Water provision is challenged by multiple factors, affecting collection, distribution, sanitation measures. In the following diagrams the specific types of threats are explained.
summary.energy: Energy provision is challenged by various factors, including supply and demand disruptions.

analysisDashboard.go_to_layer_set: Go to Water Source Layer Set
analysisDashboard.other_components: Other Affected Components in the Urban System

1.name: Basic necessities
1.3: Inclusive access to safe drinking water

2.name: Capacity building and public awareness
2.1: Access to all the skills and experience to respond/reduce risks and respond to disaster
2.3: Exchange knowledge and learn from other cities facing similar challenges

3.name: Community support
3.1: Grassroots or community organizations participating in pre-event planning and post event response
3.4: Training programmes provided to the most vulnerable and at need populations
3.5: Citizen engagement and communications in relation to disaster resilience and recovery
3.7: Main public facilities: university, schools, health centres, markets, etc.
3.8: Social services infrastructure, including schools, hospitals, and clinics
3.12: Practices and drills involving public and professionals
3.14: Major community buildings, religious buildings, and historic/cultural assets

4.name: Ecosystem Services
4.1: Awareness of ecosystem services being provided to the city from natural capital beyond its administrative borders
4.2: Awareness of functions or services that natural capital provides for the city

5.name: Planning Resilience
5.1: Public education towards awareness of hazard, risk and disaster information
5.2: Safe places/havens and the evacuation routes
5.3: Risk and resilience training to all sectors of the city including government, business, NGOs and community
5.4: Awareness of equipment and supply needed + provision

6.name: Security services
6.2: High levels of crime are observed

1.name: Economic activities
1.2: Industrial areas including ports, industrial zones, and factories
1.4: Economic facilities (banks, business centres, shopping malls, markets, etc.)

2.name: Economic Impact
2.1: Businesses with a documented business continuity plan
2.2: Knowledge to funding opportunities (for local economy and recovery)
2.5: Level of insurance cover exists in the city, across all sectors - business and community
2.6: Incentives for business and society to support resilience building
2.11: Strong integration with regional & global economies
2.12: Economic activities, including commercial zones, central business districts, hotels, and tourist facilities

3.name: Planning Resilience
3.1: Financial plan and budget for resilience, including contingency funds
3.2: Projected changes to population densities and economic activity

4.name: Governance
4.1: Changes in the overall city's boundaries

1.name: Governance
1.1: Disaster management authority have sufficient staffing capacity
1.7: Effective co-ordination with other government bodies
1.9: Is there a multi-agency/sectoral mechanism with appropriate authority and resources to address disaster risk reduction?
1.11: Building codes or standards address hazards and risks
1.12: Enforcement and verification of zoning building zoning and regulations
1.13: FAIR Data sharing to enhance resilience
1.14: Plan for post-event recovery and reconstruction, including economic reboot, societal aspects

3.name: Planning for risk and disaster
3.1: Disaster and risk reduction in urban planning instruments according to Sendai framework
3.2: Vulnerability mapping and monitoring (vulnerable groups and assets, disaster scenario analysis)
3.3: Do post-event assessment processes incorporate failure analyses and the ability to capture lessons learned that then feed into design and delivery of rebuilding projects?
3.4: Early warning system and reaching level
3.6: Integration of resilience in city functions / portfolios
3.7: Emergency operations centre: interoperability and inter-agency implementation and coordination
3.8: Disaster management / preparedness / emergency response plan
3.10: Appropriately land use planning considering risk, hazards and vulnerability
3.11: Locate the various administrative/government buildings in your city, including at the neighbourhood level, as applicable
3.12: Projected changes in location of vulnerable populations

4.name: Public health systems
4.5: Security services: fire services, police stations, etc.

1.name: Communication
1.1: Communication: radio/TV station, cell phone towers and existing telecommunication infrastructure

2.name: Ecosystem Services
2.1: Integration of green and blue infrastructure into city policy and projects
2.2: Natural elements, mangrove, hills, rivers, plantations, among others

3.name: Governance
3.2: City boundaries and sub-municipal boundaries (e.g., districts, wards)

4.name: Land Use
4.1: (identify, as appropriate)industrial areas, agricultural areas, environmentally sensitive areas, main public spaces (e.g. public squares, parks, sport and recreation facilities, etc.), other relevant land uses

5.name: Major infrastructure
5.1: Major infrastructure: water supply, sanitation and sewerage, roads, highways, bridges, ports, power supply, among others
5.2: Critical infrastructure: mapping, planning and protection strategies
5.4: Protective infrastructure: well-designed and well-built based on risk information
5.5: Water - potable and Sanitation, Energy, Transport, Communications, Health care: ensured minimal provision for "most severe" disaster scenario
5.7: Transportation: main roads, bus station, airport, train station & rail tracks, etc.

7.name: Planning for risk and disaster
7.5: Shared understanding of infrastructure risk (authorities, utility providers, infrastructure management)
7.6: Hazard mapping and monitoring (clear and regular mapping)
7.7: Hazard mitigation infrastructure, including location of sea walls, dikes, retention ponds
7.9: Areas of your city that were affected by natural hazards in the past, such as floods, strong winds, fire, erosion, landslides, etc.
7.10: Changes in intensity, frequency, and location of hazards based on hazard modeling

8.name: Planning Resilience
8.1: % of education structures at risk of damage from "most probable" and "most severe" scenarios
8.2: Adequate continuity for critical assets & services
8.3: Comprehensive hazard monitoring and risk assessment
8.4: First responder equipment, with military or civilian back up
8.5: Food, shelter, staple goods and fuel to respond to emergency of disaster scenarios
